experiences.introduction: Enjoy a day immersing in Sha Ha Beach’s watersports with help from Ah Kwok, which offers equipment you can use for canoeing, kayaking, windsurfing, and more.
experiences.name: Ah Kwok (Sha Ha)

experiences.introduction: Make your excursion to Stanley Main Beach more fun by engaging in watersports offered by Aquabound. Here, you can receive professional instructions in windsurfing, kayaking, wakeboarding, and more.
experiences.name: Aquabound (Stanley)

experiences.introduction: If you’re ready to learn kiteboarding, enrol at Hong Kong Kiteboarding School. The school provides formal International Kiteboarding Organization (IKO) lessons and kite repair courses.
experiences.name: HK Kiteboarding School

experiences.introduction: If you’re in Tai Long Wan (Big Wave Bay) and you need waterboards, wetsuit, and other watersports equipment, rent them from Ho Lok Store, one of the surf shops by the beach.
experiences.name: Ho Lok Store (Big Wave Bay)

experiences.introduction: If you’re into a more advanced kayaking experience, do it at Pak Lap Wan which is located in Sai Kung Country Park’s eastern reaches. There’s a kayak equipment rental near this beach.
experiences.name: Pak Lap Wan

experiences.introduction: Rent a kayak from Sharon to explore the waters around Hoi Ha village. Surrounded by a marine park, this place is only a 20-minute ride from Sai Kung town centre. You can also snorkel around here.
experiences.name: Sharon (Hoi Ha)

experiences.introduction: Want to explore the depths but you’re yet to learn how to dive? Enrol at Splash Hong Kong where certified trainers will guide you through confined water lessons and open water dives.
experiences.name: Splash Hong Kong

experiences.introduction: Wakeboard.com.hk is where you can have memorable wakeboarding and wakesurfing experiences. With a fleet of MasterCraft wakeboards, the company offers packages for companies, families, and schools.
experiences.name: Wakeboard.com.hk

experiences.introduction: One of the first companies to teach wakesurfing in Hong Kong, Wakesurfing HK can provide you with the best watersports equipment to let you enjoy this sport. The company is located in Tai Tam.
experiences.name: Wakesurfing HK

experiences.introduction: Devil’s Peak used to be an essential passage to Victoria Harbour in the 20th century. A 207-degree view of the harbour awaits you at the trenches. You can spot some historical remnants here.
experiences.name: Devil's Peak

experiences.introduction: Dragon’s Back offers a beginner-friendly hike with not-so-hilly and easy access to some of the most Insta-worthy views. End your hike by Shek O Village’s beach.
experiences.name: Dragon's Back

experiences.introduction: Jardine’s Lookout Hike proves that you don’t have to hike far to enjoy a beautiful view of the city. This short trail allows you to appreciate a relaxing sunset view with little crowd.
experiences.name: Jardine's Lookout Hike

experiences.introduction: Lamma Island Hike’s trail will take you to Hung Shing Yeh Beach where you can enjoy the sun and the white sand. Move on to the island’s Family Trail and be rewarded with a splendid view.
experiences.name: Lamma Island Hike

experiences.introduction: If you’re just starting to hike, consider Lion Rock. With a 495-metre climb, reaching the pinnacle is an achievement in itself because it is one of Hong Kong’s highest peaks.
experiences.name: Lion Rock

experiences.introduction: Hike on a sunny day at Sharp Peak, one of the Sai Kung region’s highest points. There’s no break in incline as you go straight up from the beach but the coastal views from atop are worth it
experiences.name: Sharp Peak

experiences.introduction: Although it’s called Suicide Cliff, it’s no place for tragedy. The viewpoints in this trail are very precarious so be careful! Snap your best pose here with Kowloon in the background.
experiences.name: Suicide Cliff

experiences.introduction: Sunset Peak hike has one of the best viewpoints for sunsets. Start by climbing the long set of stairs that leads to a trail and into the forest. Emerge to the hilltop and you’ll reach the peak.
experiences.name: Sunset Peak

experiences.introduction: Test your limits at The Twins’ 4.8-kilometre trail —one of the most challenging hikes in Hong Kong. The 1,200-step climb to the peak will surely work your glutes and legs to the max!
experiences.name: The Twins

experiences.introduction: Hailed as the hardest hike in Hong Kong, West Dog’s Teeth Ridge is an 850-metre incline wherein you’ll have to boulder and scramble to reach the ridge’s end. At the end of this trail is Lantau Peak.
experiences.name: West Dog’s Teeth Hike

collectionDetail.name: What a Racket!
collectionDetail.introduction: We’re serving top tier courts. Game, set, match!

experiences.introduction: Fancy some recreational activities with friends or family? Go to Choi Hung Road Sports Centre and book their facilities. Better yet, join the centre’s monthly sports and recreation programmes.
experiences.name: Choi Hung Road Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Flora Ho Sports Centre is an indoor sports centre located in the Centre for Sports and Exercise (CSE). Aside from a large hall for sports, Flora Ho has other multipurpose areas.
experiences.name: Flora Ho Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: If you’re into playing squash, head to Hong Kong Squash Centre for practice. This centre aims to develop this sport in Hong Kong, safeguarding and maintaining the squash rules and regulations.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Squash Centre

experiences.introduction: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre offers opportunities for diverse recreational activities. Here, you will find facilities such as dance rooms, children’s game rooms, fitness rooms, and more.
experiences.name: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Hone your tennis skills at Victoria Park Tennis Courts which has a 3,600-seater enclosed tennis arena. You can book one of the park’s 13 courts for your other recreational activities.
experiences.name: Victoria Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Located in Wan Chai, Hong Kong Tennis Centre features 17 courts wherein 3 are dedicated for singles only. Here, two practice courts are half the size of a standard tennis court.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Fancy playing tennis while receiving coaching and fitness training? Do it at HKTA Tennis Centre which is located in Kowloon Tsai Park. You can even rent a court here with floodlights.
experiences.name: HKTA Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Round up your friends and head to Bowen Road Tennis Courts for a series of friendly tennis plays. Located in Wan Chai, this place has four courts to choose from.
experiences.name: Bowen Road Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Managed by the LCSD, Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts are known for their relative quietness and cleanliness. With barrier-free facilities, the park has a Braille directory floor plan and map.
experiences.name: Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts are perfect for improving your tennis skills even at night. Open 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM daily, the 6 courts are equipped with floodlights.
experiences.name: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts
Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier

experiences.introduction: Spend a day away from the city at Tai Long Wan, a four-beach secluded spot where you can swim, sunbathe, hike, and even surf. For an extra thrill, try cliff-jumping at the Sheung Luk Stream nearby.
experiences.name: Tai Long Wan

experiences.introduction: Although smaller than other beaches around Stanley Main Beach, St. Stephen’s Beach is a good choice if you want a secluded and shaded getaway. Barbeque pits are also available for outdoor cooking.
experiences.name: St. Stephen’s Beach

experiences.introduction: If you’re a surfer, you will love Big Wave Bay’s consistent swells. This beach is the only one that Hong Kong recognises as a surf beach. Enjoy a nice view here while downing a couple of drinks.
experiences.name: Big Wave Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: On a hot day, consider immersing in Hap Mun Bay Beach’s cool waters. This beach’s water quality is among the cleanest in Hong Kong. The best part? It’s only a quick sampan ride from Sai Kung.
experiences.name: Hap Mun Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: The gentle waves and temperate waters of Clearwater Bay are perfect for chilling on a lazy afternoon. A stretch of rocky coast separates the more-secluded First Beach from the Second Beach.
experiences.name: Clearwater Bay (First & Second) Beaches

experiences.introduction: With crystal-clear waters and white sand, Long Ke Wan might as well be Hong Kong’s Maldives. Even so, facilities are limited so bring your own food, water, and other necessities when going there.
experiences.name: Long Ke Wan

experiences.introduction: If you’re visiting Cheung Sha, drop by its beaches. The Lower Beach is busier with cafes and recreational activities. The Upper Beach has no restaurant, but it’s a good place to escape the crowd.
experiences.name: Upper and Lower Cheung Sha Beaches

experiences.introduction: Backed by a forest, Lo So Shing Beach is your getaway on a weekday when you could more likely have the place to yourself. Even so, there are vendors to buy sunscreen, water, and other basics from.
experiences.name: Lo So Shing Beach

experiences.introduction: Whether you’re into windsurfing or kayaking, be sure to visit Kwun Yam Beach. This place has plenty of recreations to keep you occupied, from cafes to water sports equipment rental and more.
experiences.name: Kwun Yam Beach

experiences.introduction: Hidden by trees and tucked off the road, Chung Hom Kok Beach might be tricky to find, but worth it. This quaint beach is a lot quieter compared to others nearby, so you can enjoy a peaceful stay here.
experiences.name: Chung Hom Kok Beach

experiences.introduction: Fancy some recreational activities with friends or family? Go to Choi Hung Road Sports Centre and book their facilities. Better yet, join the centre’s monthly sports and recreation programmes.
experiences.name: Choi Hung Road Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Flora Ho Sports Centre is an indoor sports centre located in the Centre for Sports and Exercise (CSE). Aside from a large hall for sports, Flora Ho has other multipurpose areas.
experiences.name: Flora Ho Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: If you’re into playing squash, head to Hong Kong Squash Centre for practice. This centre aims to develop this sport in Hong Kong, safeguarding and maintaining the squash rules and regulations.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Squash Centre

experiences.introduction: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre offers opportunities for diverse recreational activities. Here, you will find facilities such as dance rooms, children’s game rooms, fitness rooms, and more.
experiences.name: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Make your excursion to Stanley Main Beach more fun by engaging in watersports offered by Aquabound. Here, you can receive professional instructions in windsurfing, kayaking, wakeboarding, and more.
experiences.name: Aquabound (Stanley)

experiences.introduction: Wakeboard.com.hk is where you can have memorable wakeboarding and wakesurfing experiences. With a fleet of MasterCraft wakeboards, the company offers packages for companies, families, and schools.
experiences.name: Wakeboard.com.hk

experiences.introduction: One of the first companies to teach wakesurfing in Hong Kong, Wakesurfing HK can provide you with the best watersports equipment to let you enjoy this sport. The company is located in Tai Tam.
experiences.name: Wakesurfing HK
Tai Po to Tai Mei Tuk
Tai Wai/Sha Tin to Tai Po
Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier
